markdownRemark.html:
Motivating Numerical Approximation of Gradients

  • Sometimes we want to verify that our implementation of backward propagation is correct
  • For these situations, we can perform gradient checking
  • Gradient checking requires us to have numerical approximations of our gradients
  • Therefore, we need to make numerical approximations of our gradients before we perform gradient checking

Why are Approximations Needed?

  • The first question that comes to mind is: why do we need to approximate derivatives at all?
  • Shouldn't we know how to analytically differentiate functions?

  • The following are some reasons:

    • We usually don't know the exact underlying function
    • We may be interested in studying changes in the data
    • We have an exact formula available, but it's too complicated

Defining Gradient Approximation

  • When approximating changes in our cost function JJJ with respect to any parameter θ\thetaθ, we should do the following:

    1. Nudge them by a tiny amount ϵ\epsilonϵ in each direction
    2. Calculate the following change:
g(θ)≈f(θ+ϵ)−f(θ−ϵ)2ϵg(\theta) \approx \frac{f(\theta + \epsilon)-f(\theta - \epsilon)}{2\epsilon}g(θ)≈2ϵf(θ+ϵ)−f(θ−ϵ)​

Defining Gradient Checking

  1. Reformat W[1],b[1],...,W[L],b[L]W^{[1]}, b^{[1]}, ..., W^{[L]}, b^{[L]}W[1],b[1],...,W[L],b[L] into vectors

    • Where the matrix W[i]W^{[i]}W[i] becomes a vector
    • Where the vector b[i]b^{[i]}b[i] remains a vector

  2. Reformat dW[1],db[1],...,dW[L],db[L]dW^{[1]}, db^{[1]}, ..., dW^{[L]}, db^{[L]}dW[1],db[1],...,dW[L],db[L] into vectors

    • Where the matrix W[i]W^{[i]}W[i] becomes a vector
    • Where the vector b[i]b^{[i]}b[i] remains a vector

  3. Concatenate the new parameter vectors into one big vector θ\thetaθ

    • Where the vectorized W[1],b[1],...,W[L],b[L]W^{[1]}, b^{[1]}, ..., W^{[L]}, b^{[L]}W[1],b[1],...,W[L],b[L] are concatenated into one big vector θ\thetaθ

  4. Concatenate the new derivative vectors into one big vector dθd\thetadθ

    • Where the vectorized dW[1],db[1],...,dW[L],db[L]dW^{[1]}, db^{[1]}, ..., dW^{[L]}, db^{[L]}dW[1],db[1],...,dW[L],db[L] are concatenated into one big vector dθd\thetadθ

  5. Approximate gradients using gradient approximation

    • Where dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​ represents our gradient using approximation
    • Where dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​ is a formula that is based on θ\thetaθ
    • Where the approximated gradients for θi\theta_{i}θi​ are concatenated together into the big vector dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​

  6. Check if dθ≈dθapproxd\theta \approx d\theta_{approx}dθ≈dθapprox​

    • This is a check to see if dθd\thetadθ is the gradient of J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ)
    • If not, then there might be a bug in our code
    • We use the euclidean distance to compute the similarity of these two vectors dθd\thetadθ and dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​
    • Then, we normalize the similarity score
    • Specifically, we calculate the following:
    ∥dθapprox−dθ∥2∥dθapprox∥2+∥dθ∥2\frac{\Vert d\theta_{approx} - d\theta \Vert_{2}}{\Vert d\theta_{approx} \Vert_{2} + \Vert d\theta \Vert_{2}}∥dθapprox​∥2​+∥dθ∥2​∥dθapprox​−dθ∥2​​

  7. Evaluate the similarity score

    • Typically, we'll use an ϵ=10−7\epsilon=10^{-7}ϵ=10−7 for gradient checking
    • An output ≈10−7\approx 10^{-7}≈10−7 is great, meaning they're the same
    • An output ≈10−5\approx 10^{-5}≈10−5 is okay, meaning they basically the same, but might need double checking
    • An output ≈10−3\approx 10^{-3}≈10−3 or smaller is concerning, meaning there is most likely a bug in our backward propagation code

Gradient Checking Implementation Footnotes

  • Gradient Checking should be used for debugging purposes only

    • It should not be used in training
    • Specifically, we should only calculate dθd\thetadθ in training
    • Afterwards, we would calculate dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​
    • Then, we'd compare dθd\thetadθ and dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​
    • We would never make this comparison during training, since this would destroy the training performance

  • If gradient checking fails, then look at components to identify a bug

    • In other words, we should look at certain areas of the vector representing different layers or parameters
    • For example, we should look compare dθ[i]d\theta_{[i]}dθ[i]​ and dθapprox[i]d\theta_{approx[i]}dθapprox[i]​ if there is a bug
    • Then, we may find that areas representing db[l]db^{[l]}db[l] aren't similar, whereas all the areas representing dw[l]dw^{[l]}dw[l] are similar

  • Remember to include regularization

    • If J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ) includes a regularization term, then dθapproxd\theta_{approx}dθapprox​ needs to reflect the regularization term as well
  • We can't approximate gradients easily with dropout

tldr

  • Sometimes we want to verify that our implementation of backward propagation is correct
  • For these situations, we can perform gradient checking
  • Gradient checking requires us to have numerical approximations of our gradients
  • Therefore, we need to make numerical approximations of our gradients before we perform gradient checking
  • We'll want to approximate our derivatives to double-check that our gradients in the backward propagation implementation are correct

References

  • Gradient Checking
  • Numerical Approximation of Gradients
  • Numerical Differentiation
